comment.narrative: 5% increase year over year.

In addition to several smaller activities throughout the year, the major and most impactful activity funded through this budget was the "16 Days of Activism against Gender-Based Violence" campaign which took place from 24 November to 10 December 2017. The campaign, that was co-financed and co-implemented by UNDP reached 1,5 million people through media and 4,2 million people via social media. The main objective of the campaign was to raise awareness about the importance of the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. The Istanbul Convention was ratified on 22 December 2017. More details from the following link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wAAZaA4UNAc

comment.narrative:
1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and new jobs generation. Since 2007, the Employment Generation Programme helped create over 6,700 new start-ups. 36% of the newly created start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people Self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time in the country by UNDP
2. Since 2007. over 8,300 people have acquired entrepreneurship skills by attending trainings organized by UNDP supported projects
3. Micro and small enterprises (MSEs) limited in their ability to grow and thus hire more workers. In 2014, 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their business, creating additional 119 jobs. Since 2007, 306 MSEs have been supported and 446 new long-term jobs have been created.
4. The activity rate among young people aged 15-24 is extremely low, i.e. 30.6%, which is almost one third of that of persons aged 25-49 (80.1% in Q42014). 4 Youth Info Clubs at four technical faculties have been opened in the country in 2014.
5. 1,530 active users of PRV.mk; 6,500 application downloads; over 1,5 million web site visitors
6. In the period from 2012 to 2014, 220 unemployed people got 6 months short-term employment. In average, 70% of them are women and app. 40% are youth (aged up to 29 years);
7. N/A
8. Lack of supporting activities in the area of marketing and promotion to help the growth of micro and small companies
9. National partners need to enhance their capacity for providing e-services to registered unemployed persons
10. National partners need to improve their capacities for more active cooperation with the private sector and its direct involvement in local level labour market analyses
11. The Adult Education Centre is still not fully operational; institutions' responsibilities are not yet clearly defined, there is lack of coordination between different institutions; There are no procedures for the implementation of educational activiti

comment.narrative: Limited local/planning region institutional capacities for inclusive governance and community based local and regional development. Limited funds for implementation of the Capacity Development Programme and Action Plan for improvement of the integrated local/planning region governance system of the Vardar Planning Region. Lack of comprehensive reporting on the financing of local services and limited access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Limited use of IT and social media for delivery of local services. Lack of regional and local funds to support operations and scaling up of the existing Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and establishment of new Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and social partnerships in the Vardar Planning region Lack of state incentives for establishment and functioning of Inter-Municipal Cooperation and social partnerships. The Ministry of Local Self-Government did not start updating and maintaining the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation knowledge management system and the E-evidence of established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and forms of international cooperation of the municipalities. Limited information on the needs of the vulnerable segments of the local communities related to their participation in local/regional governance processes. Local Commissions for Equal Opportunities do not operate frequently, effectively and efficiently. Lack of performance indicators to monitor and evaluate the progress in addressing the vulnerabilities as well as the quality of the most critical local services. Limited number of partnerships of the local/regional authorities with the private sector and civil society. Lack of social entrepreneurship initiatives and programmes. Limited bottom up generated evidence and efforts for down-streaming the programming of the local economic development and regional competitiveness as well as the agriculture and rural development in accordance with the respective chapters of the EU

1.1 Preparation of Report with analyses of the municipal revenues and expenditures in 2015 and the first half of 2016 2.1 Provision of guidance and support for implementation of the 2014 – 2015 Programme for the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region 2.2 Organization of the third Partners day of the Vardar planning Region and support of the cooperation between the Vardar planning region and the Region ALSACE of France in the field of wine production and exchange of good practices 2.3 Support of the inter – municipal cooperation for provision of care of vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Caska and Rosoman and for addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities

Provision of care to persons with disabilities by ensuring more adequate spatial conditions for civil society organizations to prepare and deliver higher quality services and help integration of these persons in the society - Reconstruction of a public building of the Municipality of Veles – Centre for CSOs that work with persons with disabilities
All other project activities were completed in 2016. The project is in the closure phase – activities for operational and financial closure have been undertaken during 2017.

The reconstruction of the roof of the public building in ownership of the municipality of Veles – Centre for CSOs was completed and reconstruction and supervision companies were disbursed. The Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region shall provide additional finances for complete reconstruction of the building in order to fully put it into function. Once the venue is fully reconstructed, all civic organisations from the Vardar Region, that work on provision of care to persons with disabilities, shall have available and functional space for direct implementation of activities with their beneficiaries. This Centre shall represent a starting point for the civic organisations for provision of additional logistic support, capacity building of the persons with disabilities and their families, contribute towards strengthening and expanding the network of cooperation among the local self-government units and the civic organisations, through participation in joint project activities, education sessions, seminars, all in favour of VPR development.
All other project activities were completed in 2016. The project is in the closure phase – activities for operational and financial closure have been undertaken during 2017.

The overall objective of this project is to introduce a set of comprehensive measures that will significantly improve the Prespa Lake’s overall health, strengthen its resilience, and ensure, in the long-run, control of the eutrophication processes.
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Prespa region

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

At least 8% reduction of nutrient loads (and other substances) to the lake as a result of the gradual increase of project supported measures % of hectares under Good Agricultural Practices and/or agro-ecological measures $ of area under nature-based systems (wetlands, river corridors, buffers) Quantity of collected pesticide packaging and biodegradable waste Functional Watershed Management Committee as a formal cross-sectoral participatory mechanism for integrated watershed management # of knowledge products (manuals, guidance documents, lessons learnt booklets, fact sheets and articles)

comment.narrative: High proportion of the delineated water bodies in the Prespa Lake watershed doesn’t meet the requirement of having ‘good’ ecological status according to the existing regulations Important natural landscape elements (ecotones) are being destroyed over the past decades as a result of development pressures The current nutrient loads of anthropogenic origin (500 t/year) exceed the levels the lake ecosystem can absorb without further degrading Unsustainable farming practices, especially overuse of pesticides, fertilizers and irrigation water No sufficient monitoring and management capacities exist at present The current organizational structure and capacity of Municipality of Resen and other responsible organizations / institutions doesn’t meet the needs of an integrated watershed management system Low level of awareness about nature protection and sustainable use of natural resources

Finalization of the eutrophication model and user training on model application; User training on model application (Output 1.1)
Locally implemented forest regeneration activities in priority erosion areas with plant material produced at project-backed the forest nursery (Output 1.2)
Completion of all three cycles of the grants programme to support agro-ecological farming practices; Finalization of the feasibility study on irrigation options for the Prespa Lake Basin (Output 1.3)
Launching wetland restoration activities (Output 1.4)
Continuation of operation of the composting plant in Resen (Output 1.5)
Completion of all initiated small-scale environmental/water infrastructure projects (Output 1.7)
Completion of the pilot monitoring programme (by the Hydrobiological Institute) and continuation of regular monitoring programme by the Lake Monitoring Station (Output 2.1)
Delivery of upgraded/advanced capacity development programme for the representatives of the new Sector on Environment (Output 2.2)
Support exchanges and partnering with the existing relevant professional networks and lake regions (Output 2.3)

1. The eutrophication modeling has been completed, including the advanced simulations of possible changes to watershed phosphorus loading taking into consideration projected future climate conditions. Coupled with the ongoing training programme for municipal personnel, these efforts will enable the future use of the model as a significant decision-support system informing future strategies, and development plans for the watershed. 2. Following the initial forest regeneration activities implemented earlier in 2015, the Public Forest Enterprise continued with similar action on an additional area of approximately 30 hectares of eroded land (75 hectares of eroded land were reforested in total in 2015 with over 400,000 trees). The planting material produced at the project-supported native forest nursery is used for this purpose. This has positive economic effects for the Public Forest Enterprise that is now able to save nearly 20,000 USD per year. 3. Thanks to the earlier training and on-demand technical assistance, the 77 selected grantees managed to significantly improve farming practices in their pilot orchards in a combined area of approximately 76 hectares. The positive effects of the use of the new practices may be illustrated by the following examples: a) the use of irrigation water on the pilot orchards is by 60% lower compared to earlier irrigation practices; b) there is 40-50% reduction in the application of phosphorus and nitrogen based fertilizers as a result of the more balanced nutrition. As a result, about 65 tons of annual phosphorus and 5 tons of annual nitrogen loading has been kept out of water bodies thanks to modern farming practices implemented at the pilot apple orchards alone. Municipal estimates say that the modern farming practices have been extended to an additional area of approximately 1,000 hectares of apple orchards. 4. Following the completion of the necessary preparatory activities (e.g., restoration design and review stage, communicatio

• Full transition toward municipal implementation modality is achieved following the complete staffing of the Sector on Environment, sustainability instruments are operational and UNDP-backed implementation phases-out • Wetland restoration activities in the Ezerani Nature Park are completed • Irrigation scheduling system is introduced based on agro-meteorological monitoring data and model development

The Municipality of Resen has taken full responsibility for the implementation of the project as planned. The newly created Sector on Environment incorporated the different systems established by UNDP throughout the project implementation lifespan (e.g., Lake Monitoring Station, management bodies of protected areas, biodegradable waste management system). The municipality was able to transform the key temporary employments into permanent professional positions in the Sector. The basic functioning of all systems has been backed by permanent financing instruments as a key sustainability pre-condition. UNDP was also able to facilitate the transition from the old to the new political structure in the municipality that was created after the local elections. The change of mayor and ruling political party didn’t influence the professional structures in the municipality, enabling continuity of earlier work.
Moreover, with the support of UNDP, the municipality is working on identifying follow-up complementary projects that will ensure continuation of the restoration efforts and strengthen ecosystem benefits (e.g., UNDP-implemented EU IPA funded project on Nature Protection/Protected Areas Management). One long-term possibility for funding local conservation action the municipality is actively working on is through the Prespa-Ohrid Nature Trust (PONT) that has expressed interest to build upon the achievements of the Lake Prespa Restoration Programme.
The wetland restoration activities in the Ezerani Nature Park were completed following multi-year planning and community involvement efforts, and resolution of a set of complex challenges – from land ownership-related issues to politically driven speculations about potential increase of the flood risk that intensified during repeated electoral processes. This first-of-its-kind projects of this type in the country and the wider region already started producing number of benefits for the ecosystem and the communities. The enhanc

description.narrative: 1) The staff of the Energy Efficiency Department within the Municipality of Karposh is trained in municipal energy management and is regularly using the energy management system. An effective system for remote sensing is in place and is in regular use. The ExCITE software is regularly used and updated. 2) A number of cost-effective energy efficiency measures are implemented in the selected buildings (school and kindergarten). The early measurement and verification show decrease in energy use and costs. 3) Upgrades of ExCITE software has been developed pursuing the legal requirements and in a consultation process with the municipalities. The municipalities are regularly using the upgraded version of the software in their monitoring and management of energy. 4) At least two additional municipalities entered in cost-sharing agreement with UNDP for implementation of efficiency measures and/ or introduction of systematic energy management practices.

comment.narrative: 1) The Municipality of Karposh is a pioneer vis-à-vis the establishment of a system and organizational structure for municipal energy monitoring and management. The Municipality of Karposh has established and staffed a separate Energy Efficiency Department, and expressed its commitment to streamline the energy management by developing a remote sensing system. 2) The Municipality of Karposh expressed its commitment to finance and implement energy efficiency measures in two public buildings (a school and a kindergarten) on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP. 3) The ExCITE software has been developed and is in use. The amendments to the Energy Law are expected to make the use and regular update of ExCITE mandatory for all municipalities. The municipalities have expressed their interest in upgrading the software which would allow them an effective monitoring and management of energy use. 4) A number of municipalities have expressed strong interest to implement energy efficiency measures and/ or introduce energy management systems on a cost-sharing arrangement with UNDP.
Partnership with the local government of Kisela Voda expanded and energy efficiency measures implemented in at least one public building (school and/or kindergarten).

The renovation of the sport hall of the public school “Nevena Georgieva Dunja” in the municipality of Kisela Voda completed by implementation of energy efficiency measures thus creating conditions for reduction of energy bills for the school and better working conditions for the pupils. All activities were implemented on a cost-sharing basis between UNDP and the Municipality of Kisela Voda, and majority of the funds were provided by the municipality while UNDP was mostly providing advice and technical support.
The project has no activities in 2017. Pending formal completion payment of outstanding expenses.
The project had no activities in 2017.

1st Quarter 2016 • Local Assistant for documentation and administrative procedures in the Municipality of Gostivar hired in February in the frameworks of the activity for establishing eRegulation System for administrative procedures  Center for Development of Pelagonija Planning Region • Integrated Network for Regional Development (INRD), developed and submitted two project applications, one to CIVICA MOBILITAS entitled Improving energy efficiency and using renewable energy sources and the second one to the Government entitled Lobbying in the decision-making process relating to regulations for urban planning; • Two meetings held with the regional chambers from Prilep, Bitola and Kicevo in the frameworks of the campaign for wider involvement of the regional stakeholders in the network activities; • Established business relations with the Republic of Turkey trough the chief promoter of the Republic of Macedonia for Izmir Region, Mr. Alev Sulaiman.
 Center for Development of Northeast Planning Region • Platform for Reginal Rural Action of the Northeast Planning Region implemented two training on topics of rural tourism development (“Business Ideas for Development of Rural Tourism” and “Organic Farming as a Potential for Rural Tourism”) with participation of 140 participants.
 Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region purchased 4 mobile awnings intended to cover the stands while organizing commercial and tourist events in VPR; promotional event for the awnings was held.
 Signed second Annexes with the 3 CDPR (Pelagonia, Northeast and Vardar) for extension of the period of implementation of the activities and reallocation of incurred savings.  All Web portals for investing (including e-data base) in the 5 planning regions have permanent IT addresses and are in function.
 Center for Development of the Southwest Planning Region implemented two five-day training for women entrepreneurship in Struga and Kicevo micro-region with participation of 46 wome

A process-based needs assessment of the MLSG capacities to establish a contemporary online platform for communication was produced, to enable development of a website for an external communication of the MLSG. Municipality of Gostivar launched a new service for its citizens and businesses: an interactive e-catalogue of 17 service procedures with a step by step guide on how to acquire them. It includes a variety of services like obtaining a building permit, taxi and transport licences, managing local taxes, licences for small businesses and artisans, etc. Petrovec, Staro Nagoricane, Cucer Sandevo, Suto Orizari, Dojran and Debrca were selected as beneficiaries to receive an official website according to the standards for local transparency developed by the MLSG. Knowledge sharing in Intermunicipal cooperation reinforced by the reactivation of the website for e-records of intermunicipal and international cooperation of municipalities at the web site: www.imc.org.mk MLSG prioritized the municipal competencies where intermunicipal cooperation should be financially stimulated, and produced the “List for establishing the activities of broader importance and interest for which funds could be allocated for stimulating IMC”. The policy paper “Capital investments for balanced regional development and inter-municipal cooperation“ identified three new policies to be discussed by the MLSG and its partners; The potentials of the neighborhood units to contribute to the local government system were discussed at the Roundtable “Neighbourhood Units – unused potential for strengthening the local communities“ co-organized with MLSG and CSOs’; A conceptualization and pre-feasibility study re establishment of Interregional Technology Park in East and Veles Planning Region (ITP) produced, providing a concept and three scenarios for establishment, to be discussed by the mayors of the two regions and serve for decesionmaking re next steps. comment.narrative: 1.1. The index of citizens’ satisfaction from local services - Baseline (2014): 3.34 - Target (2017) 2.80 1.2. Citizens satisfaction with the access to information provided by the local authorities - Baseline (2014): 3.33 - Target (2.95) 1.3. Number of municipalities preparing the Quality of life reports - Baseline (2014): 10 - (Target- 0)

The project preparatory activities for the preparation of Quality of Life Reports begun and the target will be measured in 2018. Due to the political situation and the political crisis in the country, as well as the large discrepancy in measuring the citizens satisfaction between the years 2014 and 2017, the first 2017 Survey will set the baselines for the overall project impact on the improvement of local services. The index of citizens’ satisfaction from local services delivered is 2.80, which shows a decrease with the 2014 last measurement (3.34). The index of citizens’ satisfaction with the access to information provided by local authorities has decreased from 2015 to 2.95 from 2014 (3.3) and will be used as baseline indicators. Due to the long political crisis in the period from 2015 to 2017, followed by political conflicts, protests and the disclosure of numerous abusers and local carriers of power in some municipalities led to a significant change of government in most of the municipalities in the local 2017 elections and a decrease in the citizen’s satisfaction indexes. The 2015-2017 Report on Program and Action Plan for Decentralization in cooperation with the Ministry of Local Self-Government was prepared. The first Decentralization Conference/National Mayor’s Forum “Getting Decentralization Right” was held, with over 200 participants including all Mayors and local administration, alongside with all major partners active in the process of fiscal decentralization;

comment.narrative: 1. Setting grounds for phased industrial pollution reduction through strengthening administrative capacities for environmental permitting and raising community awareness 2. Defining long-term basin-scale wastewater management strategy 3. Initiation of a multi-year transformative programme for adopting agro-ecological farming practices 4. Developing planning base for reducing flood risks in the Strumica River Basin to acceptable levels 5. Piloting comprehensive basin-scale water monitoring programme aligned with the principles of the EU Water Framework Directive

1. Thanks to the project’s capacity development programme, the responsible municipal personnel and the Basin’s major industrial operators have improved their skills and knowledge on integrated pollution prevention and control. A total of 16 nominated environmental permitting officials from all six Basin municipalities have undergone a comprehensive on-the-job training on integrated pollution prevention and control. Also number of industry operators and environmental NGOs took part in the programme that has been co-designed in a way to overcome some of the key barriers to introducing a more effective environmental permitting system and consequently phased pollution reduction in the Basin.
2. Based on the feasibility assessment of multiple options and approaches in terms of aggregation of communities in agglomerations, wastewater treatment technologies and financial consequences, local governments of the Basin’s municipalities have engaged in a process of adopting a long-term wastewater management strategy and identifying investment priorities. These process identified and conceptualized affordable wastewater management options for about 65,000 people living in the rural communities of the Basin. This has provided the basis for long-term actions in overcoming wastewater management-related issues in the Basin that are among the key sources of pressures to water bodies.
3. A comprehensive programme has been launched to stimulate transformation of farming practices in the Basin into more contemporary approaches of agro-ecological farming and precision agriculture. The programme focuses on demonstrating more sustainable farming of selected fruits (apples, peaches and plums) and vegetables (tomatoes and peppers). The successfully completed training programme delivered to selected farmers was followed up by the selection of thirty farmer grantees who will be supported to implement new scalable and replicable farming practices on thirty pilot farms across the Basin.

1. Capacity development assistance for Basin’s municipalities, community awareness activities and spatial analysis of industrial pollution are completed as part of the activities for operationalizing integrated pollution prevention and control system at basin-scale 2. Complete technical documentation for wastewater management systems for at least six communities is completed and decentralized wastewater treatment system is demonstrated in at least one rural community in the Strumica River Basin 3. The first grants cycle for farmers is completed and a second cycle is launched to help transform farming toward more sustainable practices 4. Strategic partnership with one larger agricultural producer is established and modern farming practices are applied on pilot plots 5. Dam/reservoir operating regimes are optimized for reducing flood risk based on decision-support models aligned with the Flood Risk Management Plan 6. The basin-scale water monitoring programme is continued and upgraded 7. Basin-scale floods early warning system is piloted

The two-year capacity development programme targeting municipal authorities in charge of the Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control (IPPC) system has been successfully completed. The purpose of this support was to overcome some of the key barriers to more effective enforcement of the environmental permitting regulation focusing on industrial operators Following the successful completion of comprehensive training programme, the responsible municipal personnel applied the knowledge on industrial facilities, used as case studies. This has provided the responsible staff with additional on-the-job training experience and better access to information. Throughout a collaborative efforts of experts and municipal administration from the six municipalities, the the first ever basin-scale spatial analysis of the industrial pollution were carried out. This new data has been combined with the river basin management plan which provides the basis for building a new system for monitoring industrial pollution and tracking compliance of industrial capacities with permit conditions. Following the findings and recommendations of the Feasibility Study on Wastewater Management Options in the Strumica River Basin, advanced technical documentation for six identified agglomerations (villages of Staro Baldovci, Edrenikovo, Novo Konjarevo, Samoilovo, Robovo and Sedlarci) has been completed. This includes infrastructural and basic designs for all wastewater management systems including sewerage collection and treatment facilities. Two local communities were selected for project-backed demonstration of the two different treatment approaches (the village of Novo Konjarevo, Municipality of Novo Selo, and the village of Edrinikovo, Municipality of Vasilevo. The system was completed for the village of Novo Konjarevo benefiting a population of approximately 1000 people. For the remaining four communities, support will be provided to the local authorities to mobilize funding from different sour

description.narrative: Urban resilience action plan and climate change strategy for the City of Skopje in place. Gender considerations incorporated in the urban disaster and climate resilience action plans. # of targeted capacity strengthening programmes implemented. # of replications and scaling up of the existing mobile disaster risk reduction and climate change application # of ICT solutions for information sharing/public awareness raising on urban resilience, including solutions that take into consideration the needs of vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

comment.narrative: Lack of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience action plans in the country. Insufficient technical knowledge and expertise for preparation of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience plans. Ad-hoc integration of disaster and climate change issues into national policies and strategies. Low public awareness on urban resilience on disaster and climate risks. Low level of cooperation and information sharing between different level of stakeholders and organizations dealing with disastwer risk reduction; Poor integration of ICT led disaster risk reduction solutions for vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

1. Draft version of the Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan for the City of Skopje developed
2. First ever Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje – Resilient Skopje finalized
3. Skopje Green Cadastre framework established
4. Flood model system for the City of Skopje prepared
5. Climate change and urban resilience challenge launched.
6. Draft version of the National Risk and Hazard Assessment updated with recent disastrous events including the Skopje flooding form August 2016.

- Draft version of the Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan of the City of Skopje was developed through participation of the representatives of the City of Skopje and municipalities on the territory of the city. It lays ground for strengthening the capacities of the local government to design and implement integrated disaster and climate risk reduction plans and programmes.
- First ever Skopje Green Cadastre framework established for better management with the public greenery enhancing the urban resilience of the city. In total 650 ha of urban greenery were geodetically surveyed, mobile app for trees inventorization developed and foundations of GIS platforms for improved management of the public greenery established, including mobile solution for citizens crowdsourcing of data on trees and shrubs.
- The citizens of Skopje are better adapted to climate changes as a result of development of the Climate Change Strategy – Resilient Skopje. The strategy includes action plan with defined time framework for implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures and actions.
- Floods hazards and risks for the City of Skopje identified and modelled for better prevention and response including the preliminary estimation of damages and losses. This type of GIS modelling supports the flood risk assessment process through improved preparation of scenarios and plans for floods on the territory of the City of Skopje.
- In partnership with USAID, Swedish Embassy, the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, MilieKontakt Macedonia, the Social Innovation Hub and FINKI, the “It Depends on You” challenge was organized for second year in row. The challenge engaged citizens and broader public to propose solutions for climate change adaptation and increasing the urban resilience. The winning solution was ReBoot – smart recycling. In addition, several other ideas were awarded and possible support: Treebook – crowdsourcing of trees and better public greenery management and Air p

- Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plan for the City of Skopje developed - One simulation exercise for testing the Plan implemented - Registry of underground wells on the territory of GUP of the City of Skopje established - External Plan of operators for technological hazards prepared - Smart City Concept and Sustainability chapter from the Strategy developed - Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje adopted and published - Priority measures for CC adaptation and mitigation as identified in the Resilient Skopje Strategy implemented - Skopje Green Cadaster operationally established

The Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje and the Action Plan were adopted and published. The Strategy and the Action Plan give clear direction for action in various sectors, providing a long-term solution to both climate change adaptation and mitigation. In this period, a few other important documents have been prepared, such as the Smart City Concept, Erosion Study for the Skopje region, Registry of underground wells on the territory of GUP of the City of Skopje, and Analyses of the legal and institutional framework for preparation of internal and external emergency plans. These documents provide recommendations for concrete actions and measures in various sectors which if implemented can make the City of Skopje more resilient. The second phase for preparation of the Green Cadaster is underway. There were slight delays in the completion due to technical glitches in the IT department of the City of Skopje. The implementation of the adaptation measure was postponed for 2018 due to the need for additional consultations with the newly elected Mayor/local government.

description.narrative: Second Biennial Update Report (SBUR) document prepared and submitted

comment.narrative: The First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) endorsed by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC (26 Feb 2015). The FBUR contains relevant data for the country up to 2014.

The process for the development of the of the Second Biennial Update Report preparation have been started by bringing on board the members of various team and the establishment of the participatory mechanism that will ensure that views and opinions of all relevant stakeholders are offered and taken into consideration. The information on the GHG inventories for the period 1990-2012 has been updated, and the new Inventory for the period 2013-2014 have been developed.

The Second Biennial Update Report has been completed in accordance with the guidelines for the preparation of BURs from non-Annex I parties to the UNFCCC, as adopted at COP 17 (Decision 2/CP.17 and Annex III). It also incorporates feedback received during a 2015 Technical Analysis of the First Biennial Update Report (FBUR). The SBUR makes a step forward towards setting a transparency framework for reporting emissions, advancing the previous climate change reports to UNFCCC. It gives a snapshot of GHG emissions in the country and an overview of what the country is doing and should do to address the climate change. More specifically, the SBUR provides: updated National Inventory of GHG emissions and nationally adopted emission factors up to 2014; the baseline and mitigation scenarios by 2035 for non-energy sectors validated to ensure alignment with relevant national priorities; co- benefit analyses of the proposed actions in various mitigation scenarios and impact analyses of different policy instruments for GHG emission reduction; technology, financial and capacity gaps and needs for implementation of mitigation actions and recommendation for addressing the needs; and detailed analyses of the capacities (human and financial) to implement each of the steps for operationalization of the domestic Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system. The SBUR is expected to be adopted by the Government in the first quarter of 2018. Because the SBUR contains very formal, technical language, a lot of efforts have been invested in producing visual tools that translate the SBUR from “UN-ese” into plain language understandable for the broader public (www.klimatskipromeni.mk ). Also, the primary information portal for climate change information i.e. the national climate change website (www.klimatskipromeni.mk) has been redesigned as a “one-stop shop.” In addition to all national policies and reports on climate change, the website has several interactive features, including

comment.narrative:
42.8 % of total damages and losses occurred in the infrastructure sector due to the floods that occured in 2015 . Increased risk and vulnerability of transport infrastructure through instability of sloping terrain that may cause further landslides, the occurrence of aftershocks following an earthquake, and possible occurrence of further intensive rainfall and flooding
Limited knowledge about the contemporary approaches for recovery of infrastructure in accordance with the ‘build back better’ principles. The current design approaches often do not take the importance of enhancing resilience of the infrastructure into consideration

1. Almost 40,000 people from five (out of eight selected) flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure 2. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll

1. As a response to the widespread 2015-floods that occurred in country’s east, southeast and Pelagonija regions, UNDP launched all eight transport infrastructure reconstruction projects that are part of the EU Flood Recovery Programme. Five out of eight projects have been fully or nearly completed producing considerable benefits for a population of almost 40,000 people. The transport infrastructure restored in line with the ‘build back better’ principles helps restore connectivity, reduces travel time and increases resilience to future floods of communities in the following five municipalities: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (over 7,000 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road of 6.5 km). The size of positively affected population is expected to double once the three other ongoing projects are completed.
2. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raising programme targeting key communities and beneficiaries. Similar survey at the end of the programme will measure the effectiveness of the communication and awareness raising work in the selected priority flood-sensitive regions.

• Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the restored priority transport infrastructure • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented as part of the second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the transport infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The EU Floods Recovery Programme – Reconstruction and Rehabilitation of Transport Infrastructure was completed in a timely fashion and in line with the earlier developed recovery plans and design documentation. Almost 80,000 people from the eight selected flood-sensitive municipalities in the Pelagonija and Bregalnica regions benefit from the recovered/improved infrastructure as a result of the restored connectivity, reduced travel time and increased resilience to future floods (e.g., because of improved discharge capacity of bridges). Communities and businesses from the following municipalities already enjoy the benefits of the infrastructure recovered in line with the ‘build back better’ principles: a) Cesinovo – Oblesevo (7,500 people benefiting from a restored bridge/culvert on a regional road); b) Probistip (over 16,000 people benefiting from a stabilized landslide on a regional road); c) Novaci (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed local road with length of 2 km); d) Mogila (almost 7,000 people benefiting from reconstructed local transport infrastructure of 13 km); e) Konce (3,500 people benefiting from reconstructed road of 6.5 km), e) Delcevo (over 17,000 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); f) Zrnovci (over 3,200 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge on a regional road); and g) Sveti Nikole (app. 18,500 people benefiting from a reconstructed bridge/culvert on a regional road).
• Analysis and reporting about changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and recovery needs will be completed under the ongoing complementary EU-funded project focusing on recovery of water infrastructure, in line with the earlier decision of the Delegation of the EU. The opinion poll will intend to capture important changes in floods awareness and knowledge that are relevant for both components of the programme (Transport and Water infrastructure), and therefore will be completed as part of the Water Infrastructure compone

1.1 Entire set of preparation for the implementation of the Capacity Development Programme for the councilors has been completed. Briefs and manuals for modules M8-M11 were prepared. The Training of Trainers was delivered to 33 trainers and “Handbook for Effective Training of Trainers with Municipal Councilors” was prepared as a resource material for the delivery of the Capacity Development Programme. The ToT took place from 16-18 November 2017. It provided participants with practical skills for realization of training with councilors, based on the methodological and didactical approach of the adult education. It also provided participants with specific inputs to revise the training session plans in order to ensure delivery of efficient and effective training to the municipal councilors. Overall, 33 (15 of whom women) trainers are trained and skilled to deliver the Capacity Development Programme in accordance with the adult education methodological approach. Manuals and Briefs for all 11 modules of the Capacity Development Programme were developed, methodologically reviewed, designed and translated and are ready to be used in the Capacity Development Programme module delivery. Promotional video for each module has been prepared. All pre-conditions for CDP to start in 2018 are fully met.

No progress of the indicators because the Delegation Agreement with the EU Delegation was signed in July 2017, and only the preparatory activities have been implemented in this period. Upon signing of the document over, 260 representatives of local governments, NGOs, protected areas management authorities, experts (male and female) attended the project info days organized in the eight planning regions country wide, and the inception workshop. In addition, the project team had number of bilateral meetings with relevant stakeholders to identify relevant project idea and to advise potential applicants on substantive matters that will help them to better develop their ideas. Moreover, coordination meetings with other donors active in the area of nature protection, such as PONT, SDC, REC, EU have been organized with an aim to create synergies and to prevent overlaps. The Call for Project Ideas have been launched and by the deadline (end of December) more than 80 applications were received.

description.narrative: 1. Percentage of prevented economic losses as a result of improved flood control 2. Number of check-dams repaired for better flood control of affected communities in the city of Tetovo 3. A flash-flood early warning and public alert system is established for the city of Tetovo and Polog region

comment.narrative: 1. Simulated damages and losses of app. EUR 11 million for a period of 25-years 2. 0 3. 0

1. The people and important critical assets of the City of Tetovo are better protected against future flash floods as a result of the reconstruction of three (out of six) check-dams
2. About 3,000 m3 of waste material were removed from historical dumpsites in the Polog region, reducing environmental pressures and human health risks in densely populated areas
3. Setting grounds for introduction of a flash-flood early warning and public alert system

1. Following the devastating 2015-flash floods in the Polog Region that caused a damage of 21.5 EUR and killed six people, UNDP supported the reconstruction of three damaged check-dams on the Pena River in the City of Tetovo – region’s administrative center counting a population of over 50,000 people. The reconstructed check-dams greatly improve the safety of communities and critical infrastructure along region’s largest and most powerful torrential stream – the Pena River. Additional options for upgrading the protection to optimal levels are also being analyzed. The reconstruction design was developed in a way to improve structural stability of the check-dams system and their overall performance.
2. Important historical dumpsites were cleaned from a few priority sites in the Polog Region, including the City of Tetovo’s centrally-positioned non-compliant temporary dumpsite. By this clean-up campaign, considerable reduction in the environmental pressures and human health risks has been achieved, especially having in mind that the City of Tetovo is among the areas facing most serious waste-management related consequences in the entire country.
3. The previous flood risk modeling efforts for the Polog region proposed a network of hydrological and meteorological monitoring stations that are actually present the key elements of the flash-flood early warning and public alert system. The monitoring stations have been provided and the preparatory construction works have been completed that will allow for their installation in the course of the next year.
1.25% reduction of future damages and losses 2. 3 3. 1

The reconstruction of three (out of six existing) damaged check dams on Pena river results in a 25% reduction of flood risk for the urban zone of Tetovo (from simulated damage of EUR 11 million under the baseline scenario to EUR 8.25 million). This intervention is part of a long-term flood mitigation programme whose realization will result in app. 60% reduction of flood risk as an optimal scenario providing the highest benefit-to-cost ratio and net present value of all benefits and costs (e.g., by reconstructing the remaining three check-dams and extending the river regulation in the urban part by app. 1 km). The project has also supported the piloting of the region’s first-ever flash flood early warning system. The system comprises of three hydrological and four meteorological monitoring stations that were made fully operational with the support of the project. This provides an excellent foundation for upgrading and operationalizing such a system across the entire Polog region (or Upper Vardar River Basin) as part of the subsequent Swiss-funded programme to improve resilience to floods.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Output 1: • Total length of cleaned/restored river regulations and drainage network (improved discharge capacity): a. Crna Reka: 57 km of main regulated riverbed 106 km secondary channel network and drainage canals (tributaries) 600 m restored embankments on Crna Reka b. Strumica: 24 km of main regulated riverbed • Minimum original (design) flood conveyance capacity is achieved in restored river sections/drainage canals • Minimum four reconstructed dams / reservoirs (Mavrovica, Drenska Reka, Lipa and Slatina dams) • Reduced frequency in overflowing of recovered dams (as a result of improved operating regimes)
Output 2: • Optimization models for minimum four (4) dams/reservoirs • Guidance document for incorporating the ‘build back better’ principle in the reconstruction of water infrastructure projects • # of knowledge products and public awareness material

comment.narrative:
Output 1 26 percent of the drainage systems, 17 percent of the irrigation systems and 3 percent of the dams were damaged in 32 municipalities. The dams of Mavrovica, Slatina, Drenska and Lipa suffered major damage during the early 2015 floods. As a result their flood control and other purposes are undermined The drainage network and regulated riverbeds in the Crna Reka and Strumica River Basins are damaged and poorly maintained. As a result they perform their flood mitigation function only in a very limited fashion.
Output 2 The operating regimes of existing flood control structures (dams/reservoirs) do not maximize their flood mitigation potential. There is limited understanding of the ‘building back better’ approach and enhanced resilience objectives in reconstruction projects at national level.

1. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Strumica River Basin are reduced by 10% compared to their current baseline levels. 2. Average annual damages from medium probability floods in the Pelagonija region are reduced by 35% compared to their current baseline levels. 3. Recovery efforts are initiated in two out of four selected priority dams in flood-sensitive regions in the country 4. A baseline on the current levels of community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs is established through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll.

1. The clean-up of almost 30 km of river canals network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – improves the resilience of the region against future flood events. The discharge capacity of canals has been increased by ~50% that would prevent average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. To achieve higher protection, recovery of damaged parts of flood protection embankments still remains to be performed. 2. Almost 45 km of damaged and largely neglected river canals/flood control network in the Pelagonija region has been cleaned-up and rehabilitated to improve protection of agricultural and urbanized land. Over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years, as a result of the improved discharge capacity of the rehabilitated priority river sections. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure. 3. The recovery of two out of four selected dams damaged by the floods in 2015 has been initiated in line with the ‘build back better’ principles. Once completed the rehabilitation works will improve operation of Mavrovica and Lipa dams in satisfying various uses (e.g., irrigation and flood control) in two municipalities severely affected by the 2015-floods with total population of nearly 40,000 people (Mavrovica dam in Sveti Nikole and Lipa dam in Negotino). 4. Through a comprehensive survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs has been established. These findings informed the design and implementation of the ongoing awareness raisi

• River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in both Strumica River Basin and Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of 10% and 35% respectively • Recovery efforts are initiated on all four selected priority dams and two of them are fully recovered • Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll • Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

• The recovery/clean-up of flood control canal network in the Strumica River Basin – one of country’s most flood-sensitive regions – has been successfully completed. The discharge capacity of over 30 km of canals has been increased by ~50%, securing effective flood prevention of average annual damage of nearly 50,000-100,000 USD, caused by future flood events with high probability of occurrence. The recovered infrastructure already proved to be functional during the most recent flood events.
• The large proportion of recovery/clean-up works in the Pelagonija region have been completed. Following the clean-up of almost 45 km of flood control canals from vegetation, the project completed additional 23 km of clean-up of sediments. Works also included reconstruction of damaged earth embankments on priority sections. Project plans foreseen continuation of clean-up/recovery work on additional length of approximately 30 km that is planned to be completed in 2018 (subject to funds availability). Upon finalization of all activities in the Pelagonija region, over 230,000 people living in the six municipalities of the region will directly benefit from the avoided average annual damage of over 2,000,000 USD from future flood events with return period of 50 years. These benefits are result from the protection of ~5.500 hectares of agricultural land, 35 hectares of urbanized area and industrial zone, and 10 hectares of transport infrastructure.
• Following a complex preparatory processes, the project initiated the recovery works on all four pre-selected dams. Two of the dams are already reconstructed in line with the ‘build back better’ concept (Mavrovica and Lipa) and works are progressing well on the other two dams (Slatino and Drenska Reka).
• The final survey/opinion poll the baseline on the current levels of community awareness on flood risks, flood recovery needs and the role of the EU Flood Recovery Programme in addressing the recovery needs is planned for the final s

1. River channel clean-up and rehabilitation works are completed in the Pelagonija region resulting in reduction of potential flood-related damages and losses of app. 35% 2. Recovery efforts are completed on two remaining selected priority dams 3. Changes in the community awareness on causes of floods and flood recovery needs and options are documented through a second comprehensive survey/opinion poll 4. Lessons learnt and guidance document for integrating the “build back better” concept into the engineering designs for the water/flood control infrastructure is prepared and shared with all relevant stakeholders

UNDP supports City of Skopje to establish Innovation Lab - experimental & collaborative space where citizens and public servants will design, prototype and test public services or products to help Skopje improve its sustainability and urban resilience.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The Municipality of the City of Skopje is the main partner and along with all citizens and users of the City of Skopje public services, the intended beneficiary of the project.

description.narrative: Social Innovation Labs institutionalized in the City of Skopje work, providing a new generation of services and servicing at least two departments within the municipality

comment.narrative: Regional Social Innovation Lab in Skopje is now serving UNDP projects and only indirectly serving national counterparts.

- City of Skopje management buy-in of the model and commitment ensured - Innovation framework for the City of Skopje developed - Capacity building programme prepared - The concept (business strategy) for the City of Skopje Innovation Lab incl service lines and scope of work developed - Physical space for the Lab dedicated and equipped - 2 policy areas selected and 4 pilots tested

The analysis undertaken in preparation for the establishment of the City of Skopje Innovation Lab show that 86% of the respondents perceive City of Skopje as not open to their’ ideas, recommendations and proposals for better design and delivery of public services or project. And almost the same percentage think that City of Skopje lack transparency in the process of decision making. 70 % of the respondents are partly satisfied or not satisfied with the quality of the services provided. All 15 departments within the City of Skopje find the lack of supportive culture and an enhanced innovative and learning environment as a reason for low employee’ motivation for innovation. This is strong enough reason that proves the need of for establishment of the Lab, for which all preparations are completed and the official launch of the Lab scheduled for January 2017. In 2016: • Innovation framework for the city of Skopje, that defines an innovation process that can be used for successful innovation development is developed • The Concept for the Innovation Lab, as space where employees together with citizens can explore and experiment innovations is designed and Action plan for 2017 with activities, proposed time for realization and stakeholders included as a response to the identified problems is prepared • Capacity building plan for the employees of the City of Skopje for 2017/18 with defined scope, goal and user segment, in order to empower the employees with knowledge and tools to innovate is drafted In addition, 2 pilot policy areas (environmental protection and sustainable transport) were identified and 5 prototypes (testing crowdsourcing, design challenges and hackathon, human-centered design, data innovation (remote-sensing – drones for improved data collection) were run to test the concept and collect lessons learn to incorporate into the framework and determine the focus of the Lab. In parallel, the Social Innovation Hub (also supported by UNDP to build innovation e

- City of Skopje Innovation Lab established - Innovative approaches introduced in three policy areas - At least 30 ideas to the 3 challenges collected from citizens and business sector through Skopje Lab - Partnerships with 2 academic institutions and 2 private companies established

2017 has been another politically unstable year that influenced the pace and the activities related to supporting the introduction of innovation in public sector, especially in terms of resources mobilization and scale-up of the successful pilot activities. Local elections specifically influenced the pace of the activities of Skopje Lab, however, by December 2017, around 90% of the planned activities were implemented.
Following prolonged preparatory and environment enabling activities, the City of Skopje Innovation Lab (Skopje Lab) was established at the beginning of this year and officially launched in July 2017 as an experimental and collaborative space where citizens and front-line public servants will join forces to design, prototype and test public services or products to help Skopje improve its sustainability and urban resilience. Initially established as public service (re)design space, Skopje Lab’s vision on mid-term is to become a Policy Lab, that will, by bringing new approaches, from data science to user-centered design, work as a research and design testing ground for policy innovation.
The lab provides the following 3 main service lines to support the City of Skopje encourage and accelerate innovation: • Continuous Horizon Scanning to identify entry points and opportunities for potential innovation in City of Skopje service delivery/products and creation of pipeline of challenges and projects • Co-design of solutions to existing urban challenges and redesign of public services • Applying new data sources for evidence based decision making or strategy development
Physically placed in a refurbished small place symbolically placed at the entry barrack, mid-way between the administration barrack and the citizens, with 3 young educated and experienced staff, organized around 2 major pilot projects – air pollution and waste disposal improvement, Skopje Lab quickly became the spot where city’s employees and citizens meet to create and co-design.

comment.narrative: Targets: - 1 landfill solution to be designed - Essential equipment to be supplied increasing waste collection capacities of at least 1 municipality - Water reservoirs to be repaired and water supply to refuges/migrants to be improved in at least 1 municipality - Awareness raising campaign to be initiated in at least 1 municipality - 60 people in at least 2 municipalities to be trained in mediation and conflict resolution - At least 5 ideas for alternative service provision to be identified. - Risk and security assessments to be mainstreamed into planning processes in at least 3 municipalities

Results: - 1 landfill solution designed - Essential equipment supplied increasing waste collection capacities of 2 municipalities - Water reservoirs repaired in 1 municipality and water supply to refuges/migrants and local population improved in 2 municipalities - Awareness raising campaign initiated in 2 municipalities - 5 ideas for alternative service provision identified and 2 being developed into specific actions - Risk and security assessments introduced and accepted by 2 municipalities.

1. Landfill construction procedures to be finished. 2. Workshop on positive deviance methods organized for 40 municipal and civil sector representatives from two municipalities 3. Awareness raising campaigns on recycling in 1 municipality targeting 1000 school children.

During 2017, in cooperation with Municipality of Gevgelija the procedures for setting up of the first legal mini landfill in the country were initiated and completed. In parallel, the design and the revision of the landfill solution were also finalized.
To comprehensively address the municipal resilience in the municipalities most affected by the migrant crisis, one of the soft components of the project involved strengthening of the capacities of the representatives of the local municipalities and civil sector activists to better respond to future humanitarian crisis. This involved organization of a follow up workshop on Positive Deviance, during which over 40 participants were trained on (i) how to identify and develop emergency solutions in times of crisis and (ii) how to mobilise support in the community.
The second soft component, which is also complementary to the hard component i.e. landfill construction, involved organising number of targeted awareness raising campaigns on recycling in one municipality. The awareness raising campaigns reached over 1000 school children in the municipality of Gevgelija, where the first legal landfill will be built.

comment.narrative: Community Work Programme provides short-term employment for 200 unemployed vulnerable groups' candidates. Services for activation of individuals at risk of social exclusion include 1000 unemployed persons registered in ESA Register, who are members of groups at risk of social exclusion

Community Work Programme provided short-term employment to 234 hard-to-employ people in 30 municipalities, while offering social services to over 6,500 elderly, children and people with disabilities and rural residents.
Coaches and Mentors, activated 1,067 unemployed Roma and people at risk of social exclusion. - 46% unemployed women; - 42% unemployed young up to 29.
Out of 737 unemployed whose personal skills were assessed and individual action plan for employment where developed, 288 persons successfully managed to be included in Active Labour Market Measures offered by ESA. 43% are women and 36% young up to 29.
In partnership with the Directorate for Execution of Sanctions and the Ministry of Education, procedures for institutionalization of vocational trainings in prisons were initiated. Vocational trainings were introduced in 2 prisons -Kumanovo and Shtip, where 73 inmates successful completed trainings in various occupations obtaining certificates for Baker, Cook, Locksmith and Argon welder.
Within the Concept Paper for Primary Adult Education, specific programmes for validation of previously acquired knowledge in literacy and numeracy were developed, as well as recommendations for a system for recognition of previously acquired knowledge and skills.

-231 hard-to-employ people in 30 municipalities, providing services to approximately 7000 end-users
-73 inmates obtained vocational skills and nationally recognized certificates
-2 programmes and standards developed in 2 key competences, numeric and literacy, as part of the opeartionalization of the Concept paper for Adult Primary Education

The Community Works Programme offered opportunities to 231 unemployed people in 30 municipalities to gain valuable skills while also providing social services to approximately 7000 socially excluded people. Out of 231 beneficiaries, 79% were women, 51% of engaged people were young under the age of 29. Six months after the CWP completion, 29,91% of the engaged people found employment.
In partnership with the Directorate for Execution of Sanctions and the Ministry of Education, vocational trainings were finished in 2 prisons -Kumanovo and Shtip, where 74 inmates successful completed trainings in various occupations such as Baker, Cook, Locksmith and Argon welder. 31% of the total number of trained inmates are young people up to 29 years, and in terms of level of education, 52% of inmates who completed the vocational training are with only primary education and without any additional qualifications.

Due to the local elections, the selection process of the partner municipalities was changed from public call to direct selection. Also, the annual work plan was revised to reflect these changes. The direct selection of 5 partner municipalities was completed after the local elections, as planned, and approved by the Board of Partners. The Assessment of the existing in-country mechanisms for disbursement of public funds to CSOs was completed. Planning and preparation of the detailed assessment to be carried out in the 5 partner municipalities, as well as capacity building of the municipal representatives and CSOs in the partner municipalities initiated.

comment.narrative:
1. Following the devastating August 2016 flash floods that caused significant damage and killed 23 people, UNDP supported the PDNA work of national partners, in coordination with the World Bank and EU. Participatory approach was ensured through the central coordination of the Secretariat of European Affairs and key work of the seven sector groups.
2. Within the framework of the PDNA works, the damage, recovery and risk-reduction needs in seven sectors were assessed and incorporated in the final draft of the PDNA Report.
3. Technical support was provided to the Government and the cities administrations in formulating of the early recovery frameworks and action plans.
- PDNA published - Improved post-disaster capacity based on expert advice.

The Post Disaster Needs Assessment completed. The document was not publicly promoted due to the delays in the establishment of a new Government after the Parliamentarian elections (the election took place in 2016 and the Government was established in June 2017). In addition, there were local elections in October 2017, and the new local governments were on board by the end of November. Beside the assessment of the damages and recovery needs in key sectors assessed after the actual flood that affected Skopje suburbs and Tetovo, this document provides broader analyses of the disaster management system in the country, identifies gaps and deficiencies and provides recommendations for improvement.

description.narrative: Deriving Data to Design Better and More Inclusive Social Services for Persons with Disabilities
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation office

description.narrative: Health - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: - Two field surveys on the needs of persons with disabilities and quality of life and services of persons with disabilitiesplaced in foster families carried out; - First training session to 15 professionals carried out;

Two surveys have been carried out, one focused on biological and the other on foster families, to understand better the capabilities as well as the barriers for their integration at the labour market. 590 families with members that have disabilities and 91 foster families have successfully filled in our survey, by the end of Dec '16. Results will be available by the end of Feb '17. Through mapathon initiative UNDP piloted mapping of physical barriers in the city of Negotino. The intervention will continue to cover app 30 cities in the country during the first Q of this year. Work oriented rehabilitation training has been initiated to prepare professionals to gain the knowledge on how to assess people abilities and increase their capabilities for higher engagement in the labor market and in the society. Additionally, one-day workshop was organized for professionals working in 3 institutions in the country, to discuss the barriers towards deinstitutionalization process in the country.

Deriving Data to Design Better Services for Persons with Disabilities This programme immanently contributes to promotion and implementation of the recommendations set with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Two field surveys done in 2016 have been promoted in 2017 enabling people with disabilities and their families to express their concerns regarding lack of services on a local level. Collection of data focused on people with disabilities has been organized in several modules in three regions in the country, involving 600 persons with disabilities and respondents from almost all foster families. Through the project, UNDP has provided work-oriented rehabilitation services for 23 people with disabilities currently based in the Banja Bansko Protection Institute (located in the South-East Region). These services included a capacity assessment and provision of tailored psycho-social and training support to improve skills and promote labour market inclusion, and are based on EU good practices. For this purpose, three workshops have been organized with 15 professionals from different institutions and NGOs, on the process and the structure of work-oriented rehabilitation process. The programme fosters partnership with the civil society organizations, in particular related to the anticipated intensive field work with the beneficiaries. End-beneficiaries are actively involved in designing the approach to better reach this vulnerable group and to share best practices from this intervention. Organizations and associations of people with disabilities shall be also involved in designing workable models for economic inclusion of people with disabilities.

1. Number of developed sexual assault centres in the country 2. Number of developed SOPs 3. Data collection framework developed 4. Number of workshops and number of judges and prosecutors trained 5. Number of conferences and number of local governance actors attending

comment.narrative: 1. There are no sexual assault centres in the country in accordance with Article 25 of the Istanbul Convention. 2. There are no SOPs in place for health and multisectoral referral and coordination of SGBV cases. 3. There is no coherent colleciton of data related to violence against women by relevant institutions. 4. The due dilligence concept in SGBV context in accordance with Istanbul Convention and CEDAW recomendations is not well known nor practiced in the legal environment in the country. 5. There is low awareness of the SGBV among actors in the local governance.

1. Three sexual assault centres are developed and equiped. 2. SOPs for health and multisectoral referral and coordination of SGBV cases are developed. 3. Data collection framework is created and capacities of country’s authorities in data collection are strenghtened. 4. Two workshops on due dilligence are held and at least 40 judges and prosecutors are trained. 5. Two conferences for women in politics on a local level are held and at least 70 women actors on a local level attended both.

In coordination with the Ministry of Health and other UN agencies three locations have been identified as most optimal and three sexual assault centres have been developed and properly equiped in Skopje, Kumanovo and Tetovo. The SACs were designed as one-stop location where female and male victims of rape and serious sexual assault can receive medical care and advice, and have the opportunity to assist the police investigation, including undergoing a forensic examination. The SOP's will consolidate the professional practice of police, judicial, forensic and sexual assault services in responding effectively and appropriately to the needs of victim/survivors.
In order to strenghten the capacities in data collection of the national authorities a data collection framework has been developed that sets out a minimum common data categories required for collecting comprehensive public data on violence against women and domestic violence in the country. and defines the required data systems that need to be set-up by public authorities such as the judiciary, the police and social welfare services.
During the project course, two expert workshops have been organised to raise the importance of the due diligence principle in the context of violence against women and domestic violence in combination with other human rights principles. During the workshops a total of 43 judges and public prosecutors from all four appelatte areas - Bitola, Skopje, Gostivar and Stip. They have been trained to more effectively deal with victims or perpetrators of all acts of violence covered by the scope of this Convention, on the prevention and detection of such violence, equality between women and men, the needs and rights of victims, as well as on how to prevent secondary victimisation.

1. 25% reduction of future damages and losses 2. 0.9 km 3. 8,000 citizens

Comprehensive flood risk assessments of the target area projects potential damages and losses from future floods at the level of EUR 6 million (as a baseline/no-measures scenario). A risk-based prioritization of flood control measures identified the optimal management scenario that corresponds to level of protection against floods with return period of 50 years. A total investment of app. EUR 900,000 reduce the value of future damages and losses for 55% (from EUR 6 million to EUR 2.7 million). In 2017 the project completed approximately half of the regulation (0.9 km) that provides improved protection to about 8,000 people. The remaining work will be completed I 2018.

UNDP continued to support the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy and the Employment Service Agency in designing active labor market measures and providing direct support in implementing 5 employment measures that were components of the 2016 national employment plan [E]. In 2017 the self-employment measure was carried out in three cycles, with a steady increase in the possibilities for participation over the course of the year. The measure attracted a total of 2,932 unemployed persons to apply for the business start-up scheme. Of these, 1,618 unemployed candidates underwent training to strengthen their entrepreneurship and management skills and 1,588 obtained a certificate upon successfully completing the training. With UNDP support, 1,108 of the certificate holders created their own new small businesses and employed another 45 people (IRRF 1.1.1). 423 or 38.2% of the newly created businesses are owned by women and 443 (40%) by young people under age 29 [E6]. In an effort to narrow the wide gap between graduation and gainful employment and help reduce youth unemployment in excess of 41%, UNDP designed and implemented Start-up measure for young up to 29, resulted with 120 companies.

Under the business support programme organized by UNDP as one of the measures of the national employment strategy for 2017, 547 micro and small enterprises companies applied for support to expand. 332 micro and small companies were selected to receive assistance and with this support created 501 new jobs. 41.12% of the those employed in this way are women, and 71.06% are young unemployed people under age 29 (IRRF 1.1.1). The new component “Support to small and medium enterprises” aims at promoting the competitiveness and employment generation through provision of grants for co-financing of new company investment and tailor-made technical assistance. This measure provides activities that help to identify micro and small companies that have shown positive financial results in 2016 and have the potential and interest to improve the quality of their existing products or introduce new products and services or expand their presence in new markets. 11 companies have applied and 8 have been supported in creation of 26 new jobs. This pilot measure was accepted as part of the revised Operational employment plan for 2017 in the second half of the year and 14 companies are selected to be supported in creation of 37 additional employments which will be realized in 2018.
